Stationary source and regulated substances handled 



The El Paso Facility of Isomedix Operations Inc. (Steris Applied Sterilization Technologies) uses ethylene oxide (EtO) to sterilize pre-packaged supplies for health care facilities.  EtO is highly effective in killing bacteria, insects, and fungi and serves as an efficient means for sterilization in systems where heat cannot be used to kill such organisms. The use of EtO as a sterilant has been the dominant disinfection method in the United States since it was first introduced. However, EtO is a hazardous substance (it is both flammable and toxic), such that storing and handling EtO without proper precautions can present a risk to employees and the public. The El Paso Facility considers safe practices in storing and using EtO to be of primary importance and has an excellent safety record with EtO.

The El Paso Facility incorporates two sterilization processes on contiguous property in the Vista del Sol Industrial Park, with a main address at 1435 Isomedix Place in El Paso, Texas. The original plant has been using EtO since 1990 and is referred to as the EL Plant. The newer plant began routine operation in 2009 and is referred to as the E2 Plant. Located on contiguous property to the EL Plant, the E2 Plant has an address of 1441 Don Haskins Drive. EtO is received in drums into designated storage areas at both the EL Plant and the E2 Plant.

The El Paso Facility is subject to EPA regulation 40 CFR 68 and has prepared this Risk Management Plan (RMP) submission because an accidental release of EtO could cause a toxic impact offsite. In addition, the facility is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) rule at 29 CFR 1910.119 because EtO is both toxic and flammable and would impact employee safety if it were released onsite.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The El Paso Facility's accidental release prevention program integrates proven technology, equipment maintenance, em

ployee training, and emergency response. 

The El Paso Facility is equipped with an automatic fire sprinkler system, both ceiling mounted and in-rack storage. In addition, the EtO supply drums are bonded, grounded and chained, and only non-sparking tools are used to make drum connections. The lines are purged with nitrogen prior to change out of drums and empty drums receive a nitrogen over-blanket. EtO from each supply drum is vaporized prior to its introduction into the vessels. The nitrogen gas is also steam heated prior to its introduction into the sterilization chambers. The chambers are computer controlled by a programmable logic control system and a system of passwords ensures that only authorized personnel have access to the controls.

Both EtO processes at the facility (including the drum storage rooms) are equipped with an EtO removal and destruction system. 

   - The EL Plant system has a Hydrox Scrubber System plus two Donaldson Abator (thermal oxidizer) units. Exhaust from the sterilization chambers is delivered to the Hydrox Scrubber system where the spent EtO is converted into ethylene glycol. Exhaust from the aeration rooms is routed to the abator units to combust the gas mixture and convert EtO to carbon dioxide and water. In addition, the EL Plant EtO storage room is provided with three safe-cell systems. Each safe cell is capable of destructing 150 pounds of EtO should there be a leak. The EtO removal efficiency in the safe-cells is about 99%. The safe-cells are activated by the EtO monitoring system (baseline monitoring system), which has an EtO sensor inside the EtO storage room. 

   - The E2 plant has passive hydrolyzers followed by active, packed bed wet scrubbing hydrolyzers which convert spent EtO into ethylene glycol. The storage room and sterilizers are vented to one of the active packed bed wet scrubbers to convert any fugitive EtO releases into ethylene glycol.

The EL Plant and the E2 Plant at the El Paso Facility are each equipped wi

th a 16-port continuous EtO monitor. The results of the ethylene monitoring are continuously displayed in the Control Rooms. The alarm set point is 1 ppm EtO. The facility is also equipped with combustible gas sensors, located in the sterilizer rooms and EtO drum rooms. Sensors are set to alarm at 1,500 ppm (EtO) and will activate an evacuation alarm in the control Room. A second alarm is set at 50% of the lower explosive limit of EtO (15,000 ppm). This alarm will activate a remote red strobe light located in the electrical room for the purposes of emergency response planning. Each instrument is also equipped with an oxygen sensor set to alarm at 19% by volume of oxygen to air.

The El Paso Facility emergency response policy involves the preparation of Emergency Action Plans specific to each plant (EL and E2), which facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and contractors in the event of an emergency.



General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps 



Because EtO storage and use at the El Paso Facility is subject to both the EPA RMP rule and the OSHA PSM rule, the prevention programs at the El Paso Facility (for the EL and ES plant EtO processes) adhere to the elements of OSHA PSM, as follows: 

- Process Safety Information - Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of EtO. This information includes EtO background information and MSDS sheets and equipment safety information. Specifications for EtO process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference. Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe upper and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes are on file at the facility. 

- Process Hazard Analysis- In November 2003, a detailed process h

s of the Risk Management Program rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process. The results of the audit will be documented, recommendations resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program will be implemented.

- Incident Investigation - The El Paso Facility investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release (serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment) so that similar accidents can be prevented. An investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident. The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented. Information found during the investigation is reviewed by affected staff and added or used to revise operating and maintenance procedures. There have been no such incidents involving the El Paso Facility EtO system.



Five-Year Accident History



No EtO releases that could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the El Paso Facility during the last five years.



Emergency Response Program



The El Paso Facility is a non-responding facility, which means that the facility employees will not respond to EtO accidental release. Instead the facility has coordinated with the local response agency to respond to any EtO release that may occur at the facility. The main elements of the emergency action plan are: (1) Internal assembly during investigation (using the EtO monitors); (2) Evacuation of the facility if the monitoring threshold is exceeded; and (3) Procedures for external notifications and coordination with local agencies and first responders.

 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The following improvements are planned in the near future:

- Development of additional operating steps and/or safe work practices for equip

azard analysis (PHA) was conducted for the EL Plant system, equipment and procedures. The EL plant PHA was further reviewed in May 2005, and then again in May 2010. A PHA was conducted in July 2008 for the design of the E2 Plant (prior to startup of the new process). Additional PHAs were performed at the E2 Plant when additional sterilizers were installed in September 2011 and April 2013. The EL Plant PHA was most recently reviewed and updated in 2015 and the E2 plant PHA was most recently reviewed and updated in 2016. The PHAs will be reviewed and updated at least every five years.

- Operating Procedures - The El Paso Facility maintains up-to-date, accurate, written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for the EtO process. The El Paso Facility ensures effective operating practices by combining them with operating and maintenance training programs. Standard operating procedures (SOP) provide system descriptions, specifications, equipment inspection requirements, and operating procedures for the EtO system. The operating procedures include connection/disconnection for EtO drums, start-up and shutdown for EtO evaporators, after-maintenance start-up for EtO evaporators, and maintenance shutdown for EtO evaporators, EtO system emergency shutdown, start-up following an emergency shutdown, and temporary operations. Also included are the maintenance and troubleshooting procedures, including consequences of deviation and the steps to correct or avoid deviations. The El Paso Facility updates procedures whenever a change occurs that alters the steps needed to operate safely. Operating procedures will be developed and put in place prior to any new process equipment coming on line, changes made in the handling of EtO equipment, or reconfiguration of the facilities.

- Training - El Paso Facility employees presently involved in operating or maintaining the EtO processes are trained in an overview of the process and detailed applicable operating and maintenance p

rocedures. The El Paso Facility ensures that each employee newly assigned to the process is trained and tested to be competent in the operating procedures listed pertaining to their duties. El Paso Facility training program includes four elements: (1) initial training and awareness training; (2) refresher training; (3) documentation; and (4) and testing. Each employee presently involved in operating the EtO process has been trained to receive the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities, including EtO emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures. Refresher training is provided every three years or less to each employee operating the covered process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures. In addition, the El Paso Facility ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after a major change as indicated in their Management of Change and/or Pre Startup Safety Review procedures.

- Contractors - The El Paso Facility has procedures and policies in place that ensure that contractors are properly informed of hazards, access limitations to hazardous process areas, emergency response procedures, and are prepared to safely complete the work. The contractors are informed, prior to the initiation of the work at the site, of the applicable provisions of the emergency response plan. The El Paso Facility holds contractor safety briefings before allowing them near or in the process area, controls access to the process areas, and evaluates the contractor's safety performance.

- Pre-Startup Safety Review - The El Paso Facility ensures that a pre-startup safety review is completed for any new process covered by this regulation, or for significant modifications to an existing covered process that requires a change in the process safety information. 

- Mechanical Integrity - The El Paso Facility maintains the mechanical

integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment. The El Paso Facility mechanical integrity program includes the following:

   - Written procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity through inspection and testing of process equipment, based on instructions of equipment vendors, industry codes and practice, and prior operating experience.

   - Implementation of the written procedures by performing inspections and tests on process equipment at specified intervals.

   - Training of maintenance personnel in preventive maintenance program procedures: safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, line or equipment opening, and avoidance and correction of unsafe conditions; and safe use and application of special equipment and/or unique tools.

- Hot Work Permits - The El Paso Facility requires employees and contractors to employ safe work practices when performing Hot Work in, on, or around the covered process. The El Paso Facility uses a permitting and training program to ensure that hot work is monitored and conducted safely on or near a process involving EtO.

- Management of Change - The El Paso Facility provides a system and approach to maintain and implement any management of change or modifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions. This system allows El Paso Facility staff to identify and review safety hazards or provide additional safety, process, or chemical information to existing data before the proposed change would either compromise system safety or require training to be completed.

Compliance Audits - Compliance audits are conducted every three years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP. The El Paso Facility will assemble an audit team that will include personnel knowledgeable in the Risk Management Program rule and in the process.
